questionListItems.title: Why is Muis offering the Muis Postgraduate Scholarship (PGS)?

answer.body: As the community faces more complex issues and challenges, we need specialists and thought leaders to provide enlightened solutions and profound guidance for the community to lead a progressive and vibrant religious life. The Scheme hopes to develop local Muslim scholars and learned persons specialising in various fields of study relevant for the continuing development of the Singapore Muslim community.

questionListItems.title: What happens if there is a disagreement between the mutawallis of a wakaf?

answer.body:
Muis encourages all mutawallis to resolve any conflict amongst themselves.


If conflict resolution by or amongst mutawallis is unsuccessful, mutawallis can submit an official request to Muis for assistance. Muis will provide counselling or advisory services to the parties involved.


For complex cases, Muis will arrange for the mutawallis to attend mediation sessions conducted by the Wakaf Dispute Resolution Committee (WDRC). The WDRC comprises experts with legal, Syariah, and alternative dispute resolution backgrounds.


If an agreement is not reached or any party refuses mediation, the WDRC will proceed with an inquiry process. A resolution on the dispute will subsequently be made by the Muis Council, based on recommendations from WDRC.

questionListItems.title: What is the rationale for having the Wakaf ?

answer.body:
There are 4 Key Drivers:

  1. To provide more sustainable forms of funding for Islamic Education

  2. To rekindle the spirit of Wakaf creation for our future Muslim community

  3. To give provide greater recognition & permanence to the inheritance donation channeled to Muis

  4. To enable the Muslim public to build a permanent Wakaf with a modest outlay

questionListItems.title: How will donating to this fund be different from donating to other funds e.g. Dana Madrasah?

answer.body: This is a Wakaf fund hence only the income can be disbursed. The capital will be kept in perpetuity therefore the income can continue as long as the Wakaf exists. In this sense the benefits from the donation will still accrue to the person even after his or her death (hereafter investments).

Literally Wakaf means to stop, contain or to preserve. In shariah, a Wakaf (plural: awqaf) is a sadaqah jariyyah (recurring / ongoing charity), a voluntary charitable endowment, from one's personal belongings or wealth in the form of cash / property for shariah compliant causes.

Its purposes must be:

1. Pious

2. Religious

3. Charitable

Once it is dedicated as a Wakaf, the ownership of the asset is transferred to Allah S.W.T. allowing a perpetual use for charity.

questionListItems.title: I have received a phone call about donations for a particular mosque. How do I know that this is a legitimate plea for donation from the mosque?

answer.body: If you wish to make any donation to any mosque, you should give your donation directly to the mosque and obtain an official receipt for it. Alternatively, you may give your donation through the donation boxes available at the mosque. In this method, no receipt will be issued.

questionListItems.title: How do I find out about a mosque's financial position?

answer.body: All mosques are to have their accounts from the previous year audited by 30 June and displayed on their respective notice boards.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find the address and contact details for all of Singapore Mosques?

answer.body:
You may find the contact and addresses mosques in Singapore at the following page on our mosque portal:

https://www.muis.gov.sg/mosque/Our-Mosques/Mosque-Directory

questionListItems.title: Can I make changes or cancel the Giro deduction?

answer.body: To make changes to your Zakat by Giro monthly deduction, please fill up the Authorisation to Change Zakat by Giro Contribution Form and submit to us by mail at the following address: Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura, 273 Braddell Road, Singapore 579702. To cancel Giro deduction for Muzakki (Zakat payer) who has passed away, the Waris (Beneficiary) can fill up the Zakat by Giro Termination Form and submit it (include a copy of death certificate) to us by mail. Alternatively the Giro can be terminated directly with the Muzakki's Bank.

questionListItems.title: Can Zakat through Giro contribution be in IRAS Auto-Inclusion?

answer.body: If one opts for Auto-Inclusion, Zakat contributed by individuals will be automatically sent to IRAS for tax deduction. For non-individuals, please declare your Zakat contribution through submission of Income Tax Return to IRAS.

questionListItems.title: Will I get a receipt for my Zakat contribution through Giro?

answer.body: No receipt will be issued monthly, instead we will send a statement of account at year end.

questionListItems.title: What if after the 12-month Giro deductions, I contributed more than the amount that is due for Zakat?

answer.body:
For over-contribution, there are two options.


Option 1: To state the intention (niat) that excess amount will be carried forward for the prepayment of Zakat for the next year.


Option 2: To state the intention (niat) that excess amount will be treated as a voluntary donation or sadaqah. If however you need to request for refund, you can fill in the Application for Refund of Zakat by Giro Form and submit to us by mail.

questionListItems.title: What if after the 12-month Giro deductions, my Zakat payable should be $3,000 instead of $2,400?

answer.body: You can pay the under-contribution Zakat difference ($600) at haul end as a lump sum through various methods such as cash, cheque, Nets, AXS, eNets and online.

questionListItems.title: How do I pay my Zakat through Giro? Every year I've paid based on the haul (period) of one year based on my Zakat due. How do I determine the amount?

answer.body:
1. First, you need to determine or estimate the Zakat that is due for the following year. For example, you will have about $96,000 of wealth. Based on 2.5% of Zakat rate, your Zakat contribution will be $2,400 (2.5% x $96,000).


2. For monthly Giro contribution, you will need to divide the $2,400 over a 12-month period. Hence, your average contribution is $200 per month.


3. Fill up the Giro form for $200 monthly deduction on your bank account. In 12 months, you will have paid $2,400. Once completed, you may submit the form to us by mail at the following address:

Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura, 273 Braddell Road, Singapore 579702


4. The whole process from application to the first bank deduction should be between 1 to 2 months, depending on the duration of bank approval. Incomplete submission or bank rejection may delay the process. The 1st Giro deduction will be on the 16th of the month. For failed deduction, the 2nd deduction will be on the 5th of the following month. Should the dates fall on weekend or public holiday, the deductions will be on the next working day. Notification will be given upon submission application to the bank and 1st successful deduction to highlight the beginning of your haul (period).


You only need to state your Zakat intent (niat) once when you fill in the Giro form (refer to Zakat intent in the Zakat by Giro Form ). Should you make changes to your monthly deduction, you will need to make your Zakat intent on the form. Also, the minimum Giro deduction is $5 per month.
